title: Can whoever designed Omnistone explain who is intended to use it, and why they would choose it?
body:
This rune is baffling. I don't understand how it made it through design and into the game. It's very obviously not good; no champion can use every rune efficiently, and you're at a major disadvantage while you have an undesirable rune. I can't see any scenario where a random rune would ever be a better choice than having your optimal rune 100% of the time.

Even if the idea was just to keep the RNG factor that Klepto had, it still doesn't translate, because Klepto wasn't purely random (i.e. the number of gold bags you get over a game was obviously normalized).

It really seems like this rune was shoved into the game with no thought, unless I'm missing something.

The definition of "random" means unpredictable, without a pattern.
Nothing you're concerned about, actually randomizes your gameplay that you can't predict.

"Random" dragons ONLY affects the buff you're supposed to get from them and what dragon spawns next is BEING SHOWN to you, 5 minutes ahead of schedule (first spawn or killing the previous dragon). You know ahead of time if the dragon is specifically worth to you or to your team and whether you want to contest it or not, at a given moment.

"Random" plants are again a logical fallacy because, same as dragons, they have specific sectors in which they spawn in. Plants spawn as inactive seeds and take 60 seconds to become usable. The spawn locations for the first wave of plants is predetermined, while subsequent plants can spawn in at least one other spot. You're never going to find yourself in a situation where it pops right in front of you or your enemy, for an "UNPREDICTABLE" situation you couldn't plan for.

Omnistone keystones cycle semi-randomly; a keystone is not repeated for 5 rolls after it has been used.
Aftershock is only available to champions who have learned a basic spell that can trigger it.
Predator is only available to champions who have already purchased boots.

The idea behind Omnistone is to have a rune that can allow you to adapt to multiple situations and plan gameplay patterns around it. Many champions can work with multiple runes and no champion synergizes with their runes 100%. Some don't even have good options but are forced to use the "best" rune available to them. No rune here is 100% efficient for every champion. That's as clear as day.

The other idea for Omnistone is to replace Kleptomancy but not give boons such as free wards, gold, elixirs and potions (among gold bags), which is clearly making champions farm gold by being mostly passive in their lane and poking a bit. This is why ranged champions thrive with it, as they can both abuse their range to constantly harass people and get rewarded for it without getting a kill, in gold.

It's not a "philosophy." You're simply wrong. Just because a random choice has constraints doesn't mean it's totally predictable and not random. When "the only thing you don't know is which buff will spawn next," that is a random dragon. I don't know how long you've been playing, but there used to only be one kind of dragon, so there was no unpredictability about it. Introducing different varieties of drakes that are chosen based on no preceding event is a random element, by definition.

Similarly, the exact spawn time and location of each type of jungle plant is chosen randomly. For example, Scryer's Bloom can appear in two possible locations in each quadrant. Once a quadrant's Scryer's Bloom is destroyed, it respawns in one of these two locations, chosen at random. The respawn timer is a randomly chosen duration between 5 and 6.5 minutes (starting after the plant is destroyed). Plants, therefore, are another source of randomness in the game.

I see nothing wrong with simply removing Klepto from the game, as it was mostly only used by Ez, with a few occasional outliers like GP (both of these being more "abuse cases" than "use cases," highlighting the problem with the rune). If it did have to be replaced for some reason, it should've been replaced with something good, not something terrible like Omnistone. Klepto was a poorly-conceived idea in a past preseason, and Omnistone is a poorly-conceived idea in the current preseason. Justifying Omnistone with "something has to take its place" is a form of the politician's syllogism: "Something must be done. This is something. Therefore, we must do this."
